;一名中国女子在高铁上煮饭的镜头引起了震惊

;

;在一名乘客拍摄的一段视频中，该女子与丈夫坐在火车上，面前的小桌上放着一个电饭锅。在与丈夫交谈时，该女子用勺子在塑料碗里盛满米饭。

;

;附近的乘客惊讶而困惑地看着这对夫妇，他们似乎没有意识到自己引起了注意，继续聊天和吃饭.

;

;这对夫妇使用了常用的手机、笔记本电脑等设备充电插座作为电源。

;

;中国铁路总公司表示，使用大功率电器或具有潜在危险的物品，例如电饭锅、热水瓶和水壶被禁止带上火车。

;

;这个故事在抖音上疯传，视频留下了 24,000 条评论。

;

;有人说：“她这次终于敢做饭了下次她会做火锅吗？一个令人难以置信的女人。”

;

;“这非常危险。如果每个人都做饭，会发生什么？”另一位网友说道。

;

;“难不成她带了一个电饭锅，里面装着煮熟的米饭？”第三个人问道。

;

;有关中国公共交通不良行为的故事经常在大陆社交媒体上流行。

;

;上个月，中国北方的一名男子因引发严重的公共交通事件而受到批评。吉林开往北京的高铁列车为了减慢速度，在厕所里抽烟。

;

;同样是在6月，中国南方的一名老年妇女在航班上与一名被她偷了座位的女乘客发生口角。 ，一段视频疯传。

;社工袁淑恩到香港旧区唐楼每个月左右，她都会挨家挨户地寻找需要帮助的老年居民。

;

;很多时候，门都被当着她的面关上。她没有被吓倒，第二天带着米饭或面条作为礼物回来。

;

;一些拒绝她的人之前接受了食物，并向她提供了个人详细信息以供后续处理。对于其他不为所动的人，她留下了有关安老服务及其组织联系方式的小册子。

;

;香港关注团体表示，老年护理人员需要更多帮助

;

;袁，41 岁，在非政府组织社区组织协会 (SoCO) 与老年人合作超过 15 年，他表示很难接触到需要帮助的老年居民。

;

;许多人独居或仅与配偶一起生活，面临着越来越多的问题她说，存在身心健康风险，但不知道可用的服务或没有动力寻求帮助。

;

;袁和她的同事有时会在深水埗的菜市场或公立医院外摆摊及长沙湾以接近长者。经过一天的工作，她成功收集了约30至40人的联系方式进行后续行动。

;

;“许多老年居民处于‘隐藏’状态，缺乏家庭或社区的支持，”她说。 “接触他们并提供他们所需的帮助需要时间和耐心。”

;

;SoCO 拥有一支由 12 名成员组成的团队，为 700 多名老年人提供服务。他们定期打电话、家访，发放食物和生活用品，为他们组织活动和课程。

;

;快速老龄化的香港，65岁及以上的独居人士超过18.8万人。还有近 400,000 人仅与配偶住在一起。其中有很多“隐性老人”，他们没有家人的支持，也不为社区网络所知。

;

;根据2021年的统计，65岁及以上的独居居民占老年人口总数的13%

;

;专家和社会工作者长期以来一直认为，该市缺乏针对这一弱势群体的全面政策，而现有对他们及其照顾者的支持又过于有限。

;

;他们说，最近年轻人离开年迈父母的移民使情况变得更加恶化。

;

;最近发生的一系列老人独自在家中去世的悲剧使这个问题成为人们关注的焦点。再次引发公众寻求更多帮助的呼声。

;

;6月13日，消防队员在跑马地的一间公寓里发现一名75岁的患有淋巴瘤卧床不起的妇女，她极度虚弱且脱水。他们发现她71岁的弟弟兼看护者死在浴室里。

;

;当没有人应门时，这对夫妇的社会工作者向保安人员发出了警报。据知情人透露，这名女子曾大声呼救，但没有人听到她的声音。当紧急救援人员赶到时，该男子可能已经死亡多日。

;

;5月15日，沙田一处公屋内发现一具据信为69岁男子的骸骨。房委会员工参观该单位。消息人士称，警方调查显示该男子独居，没有入室盗窃的迹象。

;

;一天前，一名 59 岁的妇女和她 86 岁的父亲被发现死亡。母亲节探访时，无人开门，一名家庭成员打电话求助。

;

;“这些悲剧本来是可以避免的，”社会学系荣休教授陈丽云说。香港大学（HKU）的工作和社会管理。 “每一个案例都清楚地表明了现有服务的失败。”

;

;她将这种情况描述为一颗“定时炸弹”，并呼吁提供更多资源，以确保老年人不会孤单。

;

;车站厕所按钮坏了，香港老人死亡：港铁公司

;

;“我很痛苦，没有人在我身边”

;

; 62岁的退休保安阿华*，几年前离婚后，一直独居深水埗公屋。他的两个女儿和前妻住在一起，很少联系或探望他。

;

;他多年来一直患有抑郁症。他患有高血压、哮喘、双眼白内障，右膝疼痛严重，每天吃止痛药，走路要靠拐杖。

;

;阿华说，病痛一直困扰着他。大部分时间都被关在家里，让他情绪低落，担心万一发生紧急情况，没有人来帮忙。

;

;他回忆起下雨天在街上滑倒的情景。几年前，他的右腿骨折了。一名路人叫了救护车，他独自在医院住了大约一周。

;

;去年11月他感染Covid-19时，他一周的大部分时间都在吃方便面和罐头食品，尽管他的弟弟有几天给他带来了晚餐。

;

;“没有人在我身边，我很痛苦。我感到悲伤和无助。”他说。

;

;他说，当社会工作者和志愿者打电话或拜访他时，当他参加健康讲座并在社区中心与其他有类似健康问题的人聊天时，他感觉好多了。

;

;香港大学陈教授表示，独居或仅与配偶居住的老年人面临着越来越大的健康风险以及社会孤立。

;

;“体弱的老年人在身体上不可能照顾另一个人”她说。

;

;但家庭清洁和协助就医等社区护理服务太有限，无法帮助所有人，而那些选择搬进政府资助的护理院的人则必须接受她说，由于名额严重短缺，需要严格评估并等待大约三年。

;

;香港公寓发现骸骨，这是两天内发现的第二例遗骸

;

;求助热线求助者'

;

;长者家居安全协会提供长者支援服务，约有七万名使用者，其中大部分是独居或只有配偶的人士。

;

;其24-仅 5 月份，每小时紧急热线 Care-on-Call 就接到了 46,904 个电话，高于 4 月份的 44,304 个和 3 月份的 39,933 个。

;

;一些来电者没有孩子，或者解释说他们的家人住在其他地方。许多人要求救护车或有人陪伴他们去医院就诊，而其他人则需要日常生活方面的帮助。

;

;一些有自杀倾向或需要情感支持的来电者会被转介给社会工作者。

;<预防自杀服务执行董事吴志君表示，独居或仅与伴侣居住的长者，如果患有长期疾病、身体疼痛，或患有精神问题，或有自杀倾向，则出现情绪问题或自杀的风险较高。与家人关系紧张或被移民子女留下。

;

;该慈善机构的24小时热线每月接到约200个来自60岁及以上人士的电话，约占总数的3%

;

;其家访服务每年帮助大约 300 名有自杀念头或情绪问题的老年人，其中大多数是独居或仅与配偶居住的老年人。

;

;“他们被孤独感，”吴说。 “当他们打电话时，他们最需要的是有人倾听、关心和理解他们。”

;

;为香港中等收入老年人推出300套“终身租赁”房屋

;

;“还有更多工作要做”

;

;行政长官李家超周日表示，当局将针对独居或仅与配偶居住的老年人采取扶贫措施。< /p>;

;政府在资助长者社区中心提供一系列社区支援服务，例如辅导、转介和情感支持，并举办研讨会、护老者培训课程和外展活动等活动。

;

;据社会福利署称，中心附属的支持团队会进行家访并致电老年居民，以识别弱势群体，并为独居或仅与年长配偶居住的老年人提供情感支持和转介服务。

;

;安老院舍宿位约有75,000个，其中约35,000个由政府资助。

;

;李在去年10月施政报告中宣布，目标是在2017年增加6,200个安老院舍宿位。

;

;他还表示，政府将在18个地区设立地区服务和社区关怀团队，组织关怀活动，包括探访有需要的人士。

;

;到目前为止，今年早些时候已在荃湾和南区成立了这些团队，并将分阶段设立更多团队。

;

;生命线还是定时炸弹？香港年长德士司机捍卫驾驶选择

;

;民政事务总署表示，这些团队会探访长者家中，向他们介绍可用的支援服务，并转介需要专业帮助的人士跟进。该部门还与福利部门合作，探索为老年人及其照顾者提供更多帮助。

;

;专家和社会工作者呼吁提供更多、更好的社区和住宿照顾服务。

;

;但是他们强调，政府必须首先找到城市中最弱势的老年居民，包括独居或仅与配偶居住的老年人，以及经济困难且没有家庭支持的老年人。

;

;香港大学的陈建议管理公司

;

;她表示，房协设有社工团队，在辖下公屋为长者居民举办活动，并建议香港最大的公屋提供者房屋委员会也采取了同样的做法。

;

;安老事务委员会主席李国栋博士表示，除了弱势群体外，富裕人士也有没有亲密的家庭成员也需要关注和支持。

;

;他敦促老年居民利用拟议的地区卫生中心，在那里他们可以与同龄人互动并监测他们的健康状况，而政府也可以建立

;

;社会福利议员狄志远呼吁政府在各区设立社区支援中心，为长者提供健康及情绪辅导等服务，以及转介其他专业人士

;

;他还建议指派社工和护士作为个案管理员，进行长期跟进。

;

;SoCO的袁建议当局动员各区的非政府组织招募有兴趣的居民帮助老年人，培训他们提供送餐、家居清洁等护理服务，弥补此类服务的不足。

;

;“工作有挑战性，但必须要做，不仅是是个别组织的责任，而是当局和整个社会的责任，”她说。

;

;*应受访者要求更改姓名

;

;如果您有自杀念头或认识有自杀念头的人，可以提供帮助。在香港，请拨打 +852 2896 0000 联系撒玛利亚人，或拨打 +852 2382 0000 联系预防自杀服务。在美国，请拨打 988 自杀和危机生命热线：988 或 +1 800 273 8255。有关其他国家/地区的帮助热线列表，请访问。

;作者：Rachel Clarke

;

;凯的灯光熄灭了今天早上 1 点 16 分，启德机场 73 年的历史就此结束。

;

;“再见启德，谢谢你”，民航总监理查德·西格尔 (Richard Siegel) 在按下开关之前说道。

;

;灯光熄灭后，数百人通宵达旦地进行了 13 个小时的紧张作业，将最后一批设备运至 35 公里外的赤鱲角新机场。

;

;最后一位从启德起飞的飞行员是 51 岁的 Kim Sharman，这是他退休前的最后一次飞行。

;

;“几天前我最后一次来这里，所有的怀旧和回忆沙曼先生说，他乘坐 CX251 航班飞往伦敦，于午夜过后两分钟起飞。他已在启德降落约 4,000 次。

;

;“作为最后一位离开启德的飞行员将使我载入史册，这对我的职业生涯来说是一个美好的结局。”

;

;政务司司长行政部门陈方安生和财政司司长曾荫权看着跑道变黑。他们将于今早抵达赤鱲角，迎接首日使用机场的 7 万名乘客中的第一批乘客。

;

;从重庆起飞的港龙航空 KA841 是最后一架完成惊人 47 度翻转的飞机九龙城将于晚上 11 点 38 分降落在 13 号跑道。

;

;这架飞机和其他 30 架通常会停放过夜的飞机随后短途飞往赤鱲角，赤鱲角原定于上午 6 点 30 分开放。

;

;首架预计将由国泰航空从纽约出发的破纪录直达航班抵达。

;

;其他设备将通过卡车和驳船以军事方式运输让新机场按时开放。

;

;一整天，人们的情绪高涨，数百名最后一次漫步在启德客运大楼的人们，其中包括许多过去的工人，庆祝中夹杂着悲伤。 .

;

;“收到，启德，我们会想念你的”，一位澳大利亚机长是最后一批飞出机场的机长之一，他通过无线电向塔台报告。

;

;太古集团主席 Peter Sutch 表示，他于 1970 年 1 月 2 日开始了自己的国泰航空职业生涯，当时是出发大厅的实习值机职员。

;

;“启德是这样一个地方，因为它基本上设施不足，鼓励在这里工作的员工更加努力地提供优质服务，并营造出一种家庭氛围。”他说。 “赤鱲角的规模和空间都需要人情味，我希望在这里工作的人能够接受这一点。”

;

;尽管国泰航空制定了将香港发展成为“超级枢纽”的宏伟计划在赤鱲角，萨奇先生承认，看到旧机场被拆除，他感到很难过。当被问及一周前最后一次飞来时，他是否感到喉咙有肿块或眼睛里有泪水，他回答说：“这听起来很感伤，但确实如此。”

;

;警察在出发大厅游行中午12.30左右，催促游客最后一次离开。

;

;出乎意料的晴朗天气吸引了大量人群涌上九龙城的天台，居民和游客希望最后一次近距离观看低空俯冲的客机。

;

;整个搬迁工作还需要 30 天才能完成，即便如此，启德周围的许多建筑物仍将使用，包括国泰航空总部，员工将在那里呆到 9 月。

;

;

;

;整个搬迁工作还需要 30 天才能完成。 p>;

;今天早上，对于生活在旧航线下的数千人来说，这是第一次没有喷气式飞机的轰鸣声，他们的心情很复杂。

;

;“我一开始就讨厌这种噪音，但现在我要错过飞机了。”与家人在打鼓岭路启德对面居住了 10 年的吴丽华 (Ng Lai-wah) 说。

;

;

;

;当最后一趟航班从启德起飞后，国泰航空的 31 号和 32 号登机口最后一次关闭，国泰航空员工欢呼雀跃。

;

;共有 385 名乘客和 21 名机组人员登上 CX251 飞往伦敦 - 首批飞往伦敦的城市之一。从启德出发，也是最后一次。

;

;对于船上的一些人来说，这是最后一次离开启德 - 其他人只是期待成为历史的一部分。

;

;太古集团主席苏奇及经济局局长叶澍琨到场祝愿乘客旅途愉快，而民航处处长理查德·西格尔则派发纪念镇纸。

;

;阿德莱德与妻子金 (Kim) 和女儿凯特 (Kate) 一起旅行，他说他选择这趟航班只是因为这是凯特学校假期开始后最方便的出发航班。

;

;“如果我们尝试登机的话这个航班，这可能是不可能的，但我们在二月份预订时并不知道会发生这种情况，”他说。

;

;“但这很棒，我们会喝点饮料庆祝。”

;

;一位更悲伤的旅客是前香港居民西蒙·洛吉(Simon Logie)，他转乘较早的航班以获得靠过道的座位。

;

;“如果我知道的话，我会留在飞机上。如果能得到一个镇纸并成为历史的一部分，那就太好了。”他说。

;

;乘客格雷厄姆·罗伯茨 (Graham Roberts) 说：“47 度转弯有一些特别之处，但我想是时候继续前进了。 ”

;

;欧阳莎金娜对所有的兴奋感到困惑。

;

;“[启德]是一个非常普通的机场。我只是期待着进入新的飞机。”她说。

;

;首席乘务长关国云承诺，整个飞行过程中都会有香槟。

;

; Thu, 06 Jul 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong golf course vs housing debate is really about fair use of landhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3226541/hong-kong-golf-course-vs-housing-debate-really-about-fair-use-land?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.06 08:15;
;;

;Discussions over the fate of 32 hectares of meticulously manicured land on which Asia's second oldest golf club was built, in 1911, have become feverish, with the government lease granted to the Hong Kong Golf Club expiring at the end of August.

;

;In this populous, land-scarce city, demand for affordable housing has never been more pressing, and the government has rightly decided to put the land to better use than the exclusive enjoyment of a privileged elite.

;

;The Fanling Old Course, to be taken back, involves eight of an 18-hole course, and the area designated for public housing spans about 9 hectares on the northern, generally flat area where ecological concerns are least sensitive and no major site formation is needed. Hong Kong Golf Club currently operates three 18-hole courses in the area.

;

;The government's decision is in line with its strategic goal to provide public housing. But as noted at the recently concluded town planning hearings, an overwhelming majority of submitted public views disagree with the Fanling housing plan, citing concerns over the loss of a consequential golf and tournament venue, and conservation and environmental worries.

;

;To get a more accurate picture, The Tanner Hill Workshop initiated a study of sentiment in social media on the Fanling housing plan. The study, which used keywords, was conducted by analytics agency Datago from May 1 to June 12. It returned 40 posts with 2,257 associated comments, with 70 per cent from Facebook, 18 per cent and 8 per cent respectively from the forums Lihkg and HK Discuss. The analysis showed broad support – more than half – for the government decision.

;

;Separately, I conducted 20 informal but structured face-to-face interviews with people from different walks of life over the past two weeks. Half were neutral on whether the land should be used for housing, and six supported the proposal. Overall, there was a common perception that the current arrangement, a historical legacy, is based on inequitable access to public land.

;

;Any publicly funded venue should be open for public enjoyment, like our Victoria Park, while a private club should pay market rent for using the premises.

;

;We understand that farmland rentals in Hong Kong can fetch HK$1-10 per square foot, depending on location. This means a fair market rental for the Hong Kong Golf Club should start from HK$38.4 million per year, instead of the HK$8-9 million a year it currently pays in government rent and rates.

;

;We believe the government should resume control of the 32 hectares of golf course to optimise land use and address social perceptions, real or imagined. The government is well within its rights not to renew the lease.

;

;Still, the issue does not need to be viewed so contentiously.

;

;The area's unique quality stems from its golf legacy and the ecological value of its southern areas, conservation of which is already in the gazetted plan. When the area returns to the government's full control, there are two options.

;

;One, stick to the plan for 12,000 public housing units. Or, preserve the eight holes of the golf course and open golfing to the public. Instead of housing, build training facilities and food kiosks.

;

;In the latter case, the government may collaborate with or assign a management contract to the Hong Kong Golf Club or other competent parties to ensure the Old Course is enjoyed by the public most of the time and closed off for international golf events when necessary. Thus, the Fanling golf course can continue to participate in the Hong Kong Open and other Asian tours.

;

;Building public flats or preserving Fanling golf course not a binary choice

;

;Added to our options is the recently floated proposal by Heung Yee Kuk to build more than 12,000 flats on 8.5 hectares of land in Ping Kong village. The kuk has stressed that the proposal was not meant to be an alternative to the government's plan. Research-based proposals to supplement, if not replace, the original government public housing scheme should be studied.

;

;The policy goal of providing affordable housing on government land should be applauded. Let good intentions find the best implementation paths.

;

;At the same time, efforts to host international sports events where Hong Kong has a competitive edge should be reinforced. A reconfiguration of an 18-hole competition course from existing resources for an international tournament should not be a daunting task for our professional talent.

;

;Let us put our heads together to work out viable solutions backed by evidence-based studies to improve Hong Kong's land use.

; Thu, 06 Jul 2023 08:20:02 +0800 Meta takes aim at Twitter with the launch of rival app Threadshttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3226704/meta-takes-aim-twitter-launch-rival-app-threads?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.06 07:32;
;;

;Meta unveiled an app to rival Twitter on Thursday, appearing to target users looking for an alternative to the social media platform owned – and frequently changed – by Elon Musk.

;

;Called Threads, the new offering is billed as a text-based version of Meta's photo-sharing app Instagram that the company says provides “a new, separate space for real-time updates and public conversations”.

;

;The app went live just after midnight Wednesday in the UK in Apple and Google Android app stores in more than 100 countries including the US, Britain, Australia, Canada and Japan.

;

;Users will get a Twitter-like microblogging experience, according to screenshots provided to media, suggesting that Meta Platforms has been gearing up to directly challenge the platform after Musk's tumultuous ownership has resulted in a series of unpopular changes that have turned off users and advertisers.

;

;There are buttons to like, repost or quote a “thread,” and counters showing the number of likes and replies that a post has received.

;

;“Our vision is that Threads will be a new app more focused on text and dialogue, modelled after what Instagram has done for photo and video,” the company said.

;

;Posts are limited to 500 characters, which is more than Twitter's 280-character threshold, and can include links, photos and videos up to five minutes long.

;

;Instagram users will be able to log in with their existing usernames and follow the same accounts on the new app. New users will have to set up an Instagram account.

;

;Malaysia, Meta to work on wiping 'undesirable content' from Facebook, Instagram

;

;Meta emphasised measures to keep users safe, including enforcing Instagram's community guidelines and providing tools to control who can mention or reply to users. The company's new offering, however, has raised data privacy concerns.

;

;Threads could collect a wide range of personal information, including health, financial, contacts, browsing and search history, location data, purchases and “sensitive info”, according to its data privacy disclosure on the App Store.

;

;Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey pointed it out in a snarky tweet saying, “All your Threads are belong to us” that included a screenshot of the disclosure. Musk replied “yeah”.

;

;One place Threads will not be rolled out is in the European Union, which has strict data privacy rules.

;

;Meta has informed Ireland's Data Privacy Commission that it has no plans yet to launch Threads in the 27-nation bloc, commission spokesman Graham Doyle said. The Irish watchdog is Meta's main privacy regulator for the EU because the company's regional headquarters is based in Dublin.

;

;While Meta had teased the launch with a listing on Apple's UK App Store earlier this week, it could not be found in the French, German or Dutch versions.

;

;Analysts said its success is far from guaranteed, citing Meta's track record of launching stand-alone apps that were later shut down.

;

;Also in question is whether it is the right move for Meta, which has announced tens of thousands of lay-offs over the past year amid a tech industry slowdown.

;

;'Smashed the China wok'? Chinese state media hits out at Meta's Zuckerberg

;

;CEO Mark Zuckerberg also has been focusing on the metaverse, investing tens of billions of dollars in the virtual reality concept.

;

;Meta risks “spreading itself too thin,” said Mike Proulx, a research director at Forrester, a global market research company. “Meta is banking on a moment in time amidst peak Twitter frustration. However, this window of opportunity is already flooded with Twitter alternatives including Bluesky, Mastodon, Spill, Post.News and Hive, which are all competing for Twitter's market share.”

;

;Even so, Threads could be a fresh headache for Musk, who acquired Twitter last year for US$44 billion.

;

;He has made a series of changes that have triggered backlash, the latest being daily limits on the number of tweets people can view to try to stop unauthorised scraping of potentially valuable data. He also is now requiring paid verification for users to access the online dashboard TweetDeck.

;

;Musk's rivalry with Zuckerberg could end up spilling over into real life. In an online exchange the two tech billionaires seemingly agreed to a cage match face-off, though it is unclear if they will actually make it to the ring.

; Thu, 06 Jul 2023 07:50:01 +0800 Alibaba and NetEase bet future on AI despite looming US restrictions, as home province Zhejiang vows to support Big Techhttps://www.scmp.com/tech/policy/article/3226672/alibaba-and-netease-bet-future-ai-despite-looming-us-restrictions-home-province-zhejiang-vows?utm_source=rss_feed

;Alibaba Group Holding and NetEase, two Big Tech firms based in Zhejiang province in eastern China, are betting their future on artificial intelligence (AI), as they put on a brave face over Washington's existing trade restrictions on chips and potential curbs on cloud computing services, according to the official Zhejiang Daily newspaper.

;

;Daniel Zhang Yong, who will step down as Alibaba's chairman and CEO in September to focus on running Alibaba Cloud, was quoted as saying that cloud computing forms the basis of the training of large language models (LLMs).

;

;“Top internet players are all speeding up and developing their [LLMs],” he said. “The new resonance between new technologies and the platform economy model has opened up space and prospects for new development.”

;

;William Ding Lei, founder and CEO of NetEase, said his company will budget at least 10 billion yuan (US$1.38 billion) a year to address “choke points” in AI, including algorithms and chips for large models. NetEase will try to build a state-of-the-art AI system that is “100 per cent self-developed” and on a par with, or even better than, international competitors, he said.

;

;The comments were made during a conference on Wednesday hosted by the provincial government to encourage development of internet platforms such as NetEase and Alibaba, owner of the South China Morning Post.

;

;Zhejiang has become China's first province to launch a local policy guideline designed specifically to help Big Tech firms. The provincial authority has signed a deal with the State Administration for Market Regulation, the central agency that fined Alibaba a record 18.2 billion yuan two years ago over monopolistic practices, to support Zhejiang-based internet platforms.

;

;China has started to prop up the platform economy after a nearly two-year crackdown kneecapped the country's most powerful tech players. Chinese tech champions, once neck-and-neck with their US peers in market value, are now dwarfed by Western rivals.

;

;Chinese tech firms are also facing new challenges. The Biden administration is looking into new rules that would restrict Chinese customers' access to US cloud computing services that use advanced AI chips, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday, citing anonymous sources.

;

;Both Alibaba and NetEase said they trust that authorities in Beijing and Zhejiang will assist them in their AI ambitions.

;

;“Since last year, the central government and Zhejiang have repeatedly released clear signals to encourage the development of the platform economy, which has strengthened our confidence,” Ding said, echoing similar sentiment expressed by Zhang.

;

;His remarks echoed similar sentiment expressed by Zhang, who will be succeeded by Alibaba executive vice-chairman Joe Tsai as chairman, and Taobao & Tmall Group chairman Eddie Wu Yongming as CEO.

;

;Alibaba, headquartered in Zhejiang's capital Hangzhou, said the company will fully use the advantage of Zhejiang province and continue to increase investments in e-commerce, logistics and cloud computing amid fierce global competition.

;

;Ding said Chinese companies, which used to rely on products and marketing to expand overseas and compete on cost and time to market, are seeing their traditional advantages disappear. “We now have to compete on technology and ecosystem,” he said.

; Thu, 06 Jul 2023 07:20:02 +0800 US-based scientists of Chinese origin still feel ‘chilling effects’ of Trump’s China Initiativehttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3226688/us-based-scientists-chinese-origin-still-feel-chilling-effects-trumps-china-initiative?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.06 06:00;
;;

;Over a third of Chinese-origin scientists in the US do not feel welcome in the country, and close to three-quarters do not feel safe as academic researchers, a survey published in a renowned international science journal has revealed.

;

;The online poll, carried out after three years of the Trump-era China Initiative, also highlighted widespread fear among scientists of Chinese descent living the US.

;

;Launched by the US Justice Department in late 2018 to probe scientists' and academics' potential links with the Chinese state, the initiative sparked concerns of racial bias and creating a culture of fear, and also triggered an exodus of Chinese-origin scholars.

;

;It was dropped in February last year, with US national security officials declaring a more “threat-driven” approach.

;

;“There are questions, however, regarding the extent to which the formal dropping of the 'China Initiative' name has been accompanied by substantive changes in the [US] government's practices that address the chilling effects experienced by scientists of Chinese descent,” the report published in renowned international journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) last week said.

;

;At least 150 scientists had been investigated so far, with criminal charges laid against two dozen of them under the initiative, and “many more investigated in secret”, it said.

;

;The study was carried out by five Chinese-origin researchers in the United States – a Harvard biostatistics scientist, a nuclear engineer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technlogy (MIT), and three “contemporary China” experts from Princeton.

;

;More than 1,300 “tenured or tenure-track” academics at US universities were surveyed for the poll, carried out between December 2021 and March last year.

;

;The findings come as the US-China rivalry spills over from the geopolitical arena to science and technology, with both seeking to win over the brightest scientific minds and Washington leading its allies in efforts to curb Beijing's access to advanced technology, including semiconductors and artificial intelligence.

;

;Researchers in the fields of engineering, and computer and life sciences, all of key concern in the escalating US-China tech war, experienced the most fear and sense of unease amid intensifying hostility between the rival powers, the report said.

;

;There had also been a steady increase in scientists in these fields choosing to return to China, with the trend more notable since 2018, the study found.

;

;Around 70 per cent of the respondents said they were fearful of “US government investigations into Chinese-origin researchers” and some 65 per cent were worried about joint research with China.

;

;A study published by the science journal Nature in May last year said dual affiliations and US-China collaborations had fallen sharply by 2021 due to fears over drawing US government suspicions.

;

;US 'China Initiative' stymied scientific innovation, study says

;

;About 65 per cent of respondents in the PNAS report attributed the fear to anti-Chinese sentiments sweeping the US with the arrival of the coronavirus pandemic, and more than 80 per cent reported having experienced insults in an non-professional setting.

;

;Two-fifths also expressed unease over frequent attacks by US government officials on the “Chinese government or Chinese policies” and a similar number worried that their co-researchers, family members or friends might be targeted by the Chinese government in retaliation for something they did or said.

;

;However, despite the overall fearful sentiment, an overwhelming 89 per cent of respondents “indicated their desire to contribute to the US leadership in science and technology”, the report said.

;

;Some high-profile cases under the initiative saw US-based academics' careers and reputations ruined overnight by their suspected Chinese links.

;

;In 2021, Chinese-born professor Gang Chen, former head of mechanical engineering at MIT and a member of the US National Academy of Engineering, was accused of lying about China ties in funding papers. He was arrested, his lab was closed and his research group was disbanded. But all charges were dropped a year later, with the Justice Department admitting it could not prove its case.

;

;China-born scientist targeted by US 'discovers world's best semiconductor'

;

;Non-Chinese academics were also caught up in the campaign. In April, retired Harvard professor Charles Lieber was placed under house arrest for six months and fined hundreds of thousands of dollars after being convicted in 2021 of trying to deny his ties to China and participation in Beijing's Thousand Talents Programme, a project to recruit scientists and strengthen research.

;

;The five scientists behind the PNAS report said they carried out the poll on behalf of the Asian American Scholar Forum, a non-profit organisation set up in response to Gang's case “to promote academic belonging, openness, freedom, and equality for all”.

;

;US suspicion of Chinese scientists actually predates the launch of the China Initiative. Sherry Chen, a National Weather Service hydrologist, was accused of spying for China a decade ago. Last November, she received US$550,000, and an additional US$1.25 million over 10 years, as settlement for the wrongful prosecution.

;

;A number of Chinese scientists have given up their US citizenship since the launch of the China Initiative.

;

;The latest to do so was biophysical chemist Xie Xiaoliang, who returned to China last month. The former Harvard professor is best known for helping to invent the single-cell DNA amplification method in 2012.

;

;Zhu Songchun, an accomplished computer scientist, gave up a professorship at the University of California, Los Angeles to become dean of the Institute for AI at Peking University in 2020.

; Thu, 06 Jul 2023 06:50:02 +0800 Thailand’s Pita Limjaroenrat confident of being named PM as parliament sets July 13 votehttps://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3226671/thailands-pita-limjaroenrat-confident-being-named-pm-parliament-sets-july-13-vote?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.06 06:30;
;;

;Thailand will hold a joint session of its parliament on July 13 to elect a prime minister, taking a key step toward government formation almost two months after a group of pro-democracy parties swept the May election.

;

;The 750-member National Assembly will convene for the vote at 9:30am next Thursday, Wan Muhamad Noor Matha, newly-elected speaker of the House of Representatives, told reporters on Wednesday. The session may not be immediately conclusive and may be only the first of many, as a successful premier candidate needs to gain the support of most lawmakers, he said.

;

;The eight-party coalition that has staked a claim to form Thailand's next government will solely nominate Pita Limjaroenrat, the 42-year-old leader of the progressive Move Forward Party that won the most seats in the May 14 election. It is not yet clear if other parties will nominate someone to challenge Pita's bid.

;

;Thai parliament to convene session on July 3 enabling vote for new PM

;

;The coalition Pita's cobbled together after the election currently commands 312 lawmakers, a clear majority in the 500-member House of Representatives. But he needs the support of over a fourth of the 250-member Senate – a body appointed by the royalist military establishment following a 2014 coup that will vote alongside the lower chamber.

;

;Many senators oppose his Move Forward Party's proposal to amend the lese-majesty law, or Article 112 of the Thai criminal code, which penalises criticisms against the king and other royals.

;

;As the house speaker usually abstains from taking sides with any group, the coalition is likely to be down one vote in support for Pita, leaving him still short of about 65 votes to reach the 376-vote marker to secure the premiership.

;

;As Pita has ruled out alliances with conservative parties, there is little alternative but to win as many Senate votes as possible.

;

;Despite the uphill battle, Pita has said that he is confident he will secure the top job.

;

;A long drawn-out government formation may further spook investors in the Thai financial markets. While the nation's benchmark stock index is the worst performer in Asia this year, the baht is the second-biggest loser in Southeast Asia since the May 14 vote.

;

;There is no deadline for when the next leader has to be elected by, and the parliament may need to convene more than once to vote until a clear winner emerges, Wan said.

;

;Asked how many times such a vote may take place, the 79-year-old speaker said: “We cannot anticipate in advance.”

;

;Additional reporting by Agence France-Presse
